title.rendered: Valve makes a firm decision on NFTs and cryptocurrencies on Steam and Gabe Newell explains why

content.rendered:
Valve has taken a position against NFTs and cryptocurrencies being allowed on Steam, blocking games that incorporate blockchain technology. Its president and co-founder, Gabe Newell, has now explained the reasons for his decision, stating that the biggest problems are the volatility of cryptocurrencies and the bad examples behind the uses of these technologies.

In an interview with Rock Paper Shotgun, Newell noted that it’s important to separate NFT technology from users. The concepts of digital ownership and shared universes are fine by themselves, he said, but believes the bad examples from the NFT community outweigh any potential positives.

“People in this sector tend to be involved in many criminal activities and unclear behaviors“, said. “So it’s much more about the actors than the underlying technology.“.

Furthermore, he explains that these people are not the ones that Valve wants to do business with. For him, the space is full of people using NFTs as an opportunity to scam customers or engage in money laundering.

Also, when Steam accepted cryptocurrencies as payment for games, the huge volatility that came with it was problematic for users. When it comes to buying everyday items, customers don’t want the price to fluctuate as much. “Why one day I spend 497 dollars to buy a game and the next day I spend 47 cents, what is happening here? Volatility is a bad thing in a medium of exchange“, he explained.

He also said that the vast majority of cryptocurrency transactions on Steam were fraudulent. Although fraud is not something that can be completely eliminated, ideally fraud cases should only contribute to a couple of percentages of total transactions. However, with fraud making up half of all crypto transactions, he said, “It’s out of control, right?”

Regarding the concept of digital property and the metaverse, Newell brought up Final Fantasy 14 in another interview with PCGamer. “Most people who talk about the metaverse have no idea what they’re talking about. And apparently they’ve never played an MMO“he explained.”They say, ‘Oh, you’ll have this customizable avatar.’ And it’s like, well… walk into La Noscea in Final Fantasy 14 and tell me this isn’t a problem solved from a decade agonot a fabulous thing that you’re, you know, making up“.

Luckily, Final Fantasy 14 won’t have NFTs either.
